[FINDING]
Category: mathematical_error
Severity: critical
Line: 71
Quote: "The R-square measure of correlation between two sets of data is the same as the cosine of the angle between them when presented as vectors in N-dimensional space"
Issue: This is incorrect. The correlation coefficient R (not R²) equals the cosine of the angle between centered vectors. R² is the square of the correlation coefficient.
[/FINDING]

[FINDING]
Category: mathematical_error
Severity: critical
Line: 75
Quote: "Grant a factor correlated with an outcome, which we represent with two vectors at an angle theta, the inverse cosine equal the R-squared."
Issue: The angle theta's cosine equals R (the correlation coefficient), not R². The inverse cosine (arccos) of R gives the angle, not the inverse cosine of R².
[/FINDING]

[FINDING]
Category: factual_error
Severity: major
Line: 75
Quote: "an R-square of 0.5 (corresponding to an angle of sixty degrees)"
Issue: An R² of 0.5 means R ≈ 0.707, which corresponds to an angle of approximately 45 degrees, not 60 degrees. A 60-degree angle would give cos(60°) = 0.5, meaning R = 0.5 and R² = 0.25.
[/FINDING]

[FINDING]
Category: factual_error
Severity: major
Line: 87
Quote: "if Bill Gates is ~+4SD in intelligence, despite being the richest man in america"
Issue: Bill Gates has not been the richest person in America for several years. As of the document's 2014 date and updates, this claim was becoming outdated.
[/FINDING]

[FINDING]
Category: unsupported_claim
Severity: major
Line: 15
Quote: "Maybe a high IQ is good for earning money, but a stratospherically high IQ has an increased risk of productivity-reducing mental illness"
Issue: The linked source does not provide robust empirical evidence for increased mental illness at very high IQ levels. This claim requires stronger scientific support.
[/FINDING]

[FINDING]
Category: mathematical_error
Severity: minor
Line: 99
Quote: "Another intuitive dividend is that this makes it clear why you can by R-squared to move between z-scores of correlated normal variables"
Issue: The text appears to have a typo ("can by" should likely be "can multiply by"), but more importantly, you multiply by R (not R²) to convert between z-scores of correlated variables.
[/FINDING]

[FINDING]
Category: spelling_grammar
Severity: minor
Line: 23
Quote: "comparing the speed of a ball out of a baseball pitchers hand compared to its speed crossing crossing the plate"
Issue: Word repetition error - "crossing" appears twice.
[/FINDING]
